India news Mann Ki Baat: PM Narendra Modi hails Mahatma Gandhi, Bhagat Singh, Sukhdev and Rajguru; eyes transition to a new India for its 1.25 bn population Mann Ki Baat: PM Narendra Modi hails Mahatma Gandhi, Bhagat Singh, Sukhdev and Rajguru; eyes transition to a new India for its 1.25 bn population Prime Minister Narendra Modi addressed the 30th edition of his monthly radio broadcast ‘Mann Ki Baat’ today. By: FE Online | New Delhi | Updated: March 26, 2017 11:25 AM Prime Minister Narendra Modi. (PTI) 
Prime Minister Narendra Modi addressed the 30th edition of his monthly radio broadcast ‘Mann Ki Baat’ today which is also the first radio address post poll. PM Modi started the show by extending his heartfelt greetings to the people of Bangladesh on their Independence Day today. While talking about freedom fighters, he said, “On the 23rd of March, Bhagat Singh Ji and his comrades, Sukhdev and Rajguru, were hanged to death by the British.” He further added, “There was a sense of fulfilment on faces of Bhagat Singh, Sukhdev and Rajguru for having served Mother India and there was no fear of death.” 
While Talking about Father of the Nation, Mahatma Gandhi, he said, “On 10th of April 1917, Mahatma Gandhi launched the Champaran Satyagraha.This year marks the centenary of the Champaran Satyagraha.” He further added, “We cannot evaluate the Champaran Satyagraha on the basis of the image of Mahatma Gandhi that we cherish in our hearts today.” 
PM then talked about ‘New India’ and said, “We live in the 21st century. The desire of 125 cr countrymen for change, effort to change, is what will lay a strong foundation of ‘New India’. It is the essence of the emotions of the 125 crore Indians wanting to come together and create a magnificent India.”

The programme was started by the PM on October 3, 2014. PM Modi on the 29th edition of the show talked about his Swachch Bharat scheme, the BHIM app and the other schemes launched by the government in public interest. In the last address, he gave several exam tips to the students who were waiting for their board examination.
